Query: How to enable or disable a user?

Answers.Most Similar TLDR Task: Change the password of the specified user
Top-3 Similar Questions: au_44418: How to enable root login?
au_160802: I enabled the root account by mistake, how do I disable it?
su_926180: linux - enabling system user to login?
Top-3 Scripts:
au_44418: sudo passwd root

passwd root

sudo passwd -u root

sudo passwd -l root

au_160802: sudo passwd -dl root

sudo passwd username

Explanations about Options.-l:
Lock the password of the named account. This option disables a password by changing it
 to a value which matches no possible encrypted value (it adds a ´!´ at the beginning
 of the password).

Top-3 Similar Questions: su_926180: linux - enabling system user to login?
ul_520368: How do I disable login of user?
Top-3 Scripts:
ul_520368: Note that this does not disable the account. The user may
       still be able to login using another authentication token
       (e.g. an SSH key). To disable the account, administrators
       should use usermod --expiredate 1 (this set the account's
       expire date to Jan 2, 1970).

       Users with a locked password are not allowed to change
       their password.

au_24110: sudo usermod -s /bin/false <account>

sudo usermod -s /bin/false baduser

Explanations about Options.-s:
The name of the user's new login shell. Setting this field to blank causes the system
 to select the default login shell.
Explanations about Options.--expiredate:
The date on which the user account will be disabled. The date is specified in the
 format YYYY-MM-DD.

Answers.Most Similar TLDR Task: Login as a user on a remote host

Top-3 Scripts:
ul_520368: Note that this does not disable the account. The user may
       still be able to login using another authentication token
       (e.g. an SSH key). To disable the account, administrators
       should use usermod --expiredate 1 (this set the account's
       expire date to Jan 2, 1970).

       Users with a locked password are not allowed to change

ul_121618: The su command is used to become another user during a login session.
   Invoked without a username, su defaults to becoming the superuser. The
   optional argument - may be used to provide an environment similar to
   what the user would expect had the user logged in directly.

Answers.MP Summary: enable or disable an apache2 configuration file
enable or disable an apache2 module
Top-3 Similar Questions: au_1129902: How to enable modstatus into apache?
Top-3 Scripts:
au_1129902: doug@DOUG-64:~$ cd ~/config/etc/apache2/mods-available
doug@DOUG-64:~/config/etc/apache2/mods-available$ cp /etc/apache2/mods-available/status.conf ./
doug@DOUG-64:~/config/etc/apache2/mods-available$ cp status.conf status.conf.16.04.original
doug@DOUG-64:~/config/etc/apache2/mods-available$ nano status.conf
doug@DOUG-64:~/config/etc/apache2/mods-available$ cp status.conf status.conf.doug
doug@DOUG-64:~/config/etc/apache2/mods-available$ sudo cp status.conf /etc/apache2/mods-available/status.conf
doug@DOUG-64:~/config/etc/apache2/mods-available$ sudo a2enmod status
doug@DOUG-64:~/config/etc/apache2/mods-available$ sudo systemctl restart apache2
